direction.raw_text: One of the broken wires holding the panel is longer than the other, cocking the sign irregularly. The railroad tracks reach endlessly into the horizon. Past the town on each side stretches the ocean-like prairie, with sand dunes rising and falling monotonously, shouldering each other toward infinity. The morning sun lays over this wasteland of the American Southwest, a gigantic yellow bruise from which heat waves like bloodshot arteries spread themselves over the poisoned sky. A small shack stands next to the station, separated from it by a narrow alleyway and leaning toward the larger building, as if for support. The words POSTAL TELEGRAPH are arced across its dusty vitrine. An old straight-backed chair, reinforced with twisted wire, is tilted against the north-west corner of the shack. In it is Mr. Hastings, the postal telegraph agent, a man of middle years and exorbitant mediocrity. He sits there spinelessly, fingering a wart on his receding chin and, once in a while, for variety, rubbing a knuckle under his watery nose.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The town is minute, dismal and forgotten, crouching in isolation where the single line of railroad track intersects a secondary dirt road. The twin strips of steel glisten in the fierce sunlight, fencing the dreary plain from the false fronts of the town. In b.g. is the bluff of a black stony mountain. Against this ancient mass the houses of Black Rock's single street*** (See map, P.2A) are scanty in number and insignificant in architecture, a conglomerate paint-peeled modern trussed together with rusty nails and battered tin strips torn from signs. The town and the terrain surrounding it have, if nothing else, the quality of inertia and immutibility -- nothing moves, not even an insect; nothing breathes, not even the wind. Town and terrain seem to be trapped, caught and held forever in the sullen, abrasive earth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sequence omitted from original script.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: jarring in its power as it ramrods across the desert, its diesel engines pounding. Its horn "WONKS" twice, blasting the shatterable air.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - ANOTHER ANGLE Nothing is changed, nothing is altered. But look close and you will see a small shallow current of wind sweeping lazily across the dirt and dust of the single street. HOLD for a beat, then MAIN TITLE appears. Between the ensuing credits INTERCUT a series of sharp LONG SHOTS. The composition of each shot has that hard, sun-beaten texture of American primitive painting -- pressurized in its simplicity -- best exemplified, perhaps, by the work of Grant Wood.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: assayer and notary public, mortician to the citizens of Black Rock who have departed to a better place, and veterinarian to its lesser animals. An elderly, somewhat untidy gentleman, he sits nonchalantly on a chair outside the Bar & Grill. Idling with him are three or four other loafers, among them Sam, the middle-aged proprietor of the restaurant. Doc glances casually at his watch; no one else moves. The hot wind continues listlessly down the empty street.

The sultry wind, its gustiness slightly increased, blows through her fine dark hair.

She cuts speed, brakes hissing, and starts to slow down.

direction.raw_text: with the train stationary before it. A sleek steel door of a pullman clangs open. A colored porter carrying a suitcase walks down the wrought-iron steps. He is stately, gray-haired and lean, with the almost finical tidiness travelers associate with trainmen. The man behind him is big-shouldered, a granite- like wedge of a man with calm, piercing eyes. There is about him an air of monumental dependability and quiet humor, but his eyes are those of a man who has lately lived in somber familiarity with pain. His left arm hangs from his shoulder with that lifeless rigidity of paralysis, while the hand is hidden in his pocket.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The porter puts the suitcase on the platform. In the distance the town and its people are seen staring silently, motionlessly. The big man glances toward them. He smiles a sad, distasteful greeting to the town, its wretched dust. its mean, modest buildings. The porter disappears into the train as the conductor enters scene. He turns slowly, following Macreedy's gaze...

direction.raw_text: Macreedy nods his thanks. The conductor signals the engineer (o.s.) and steps on the train. The diesel's claxon blasts the torrid air ominously. The train slowly, smoothly, begins to move, picking up speed. The cars slip past until, quite suddenly, the Streamliner is gone. For a moment Macreedy watches it. Then, quite unconsciously, he takes a package of cigarettes from his left hand pocket, taps the last one free of the pack, sticks it between his lips and, crumpling the empty pack, drops it beside the tracks. He takes a cardboard book of matches, flicks it open, bends a match in half with agile fingers, and with a sure frictional motion scrapes the head against the sandpaper guard. The match flares, the cigarette is lit. Macreedy inhales, exhales deeply, and turns to pick up his suitcase. Then he sees Hastings, who walks slowly, almost painfully, to him. His Adam's apple grapples protestingly with his collar. After a moment he controls it sufficiently to talk...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - MACREEDY heading toward the hotel. In b.g. is a relatively small farm equipment yard compressed between a general store (which Macreedy has just passed) and the hotel just ahead. In the yard are a few tractors, and among them huddles a tiny office. It is empty; the front window is thick with dust. On it, etched by an anonymous, childish finger, is a skull and crossbones. Running diagonally across is the printed legend: T.J. HATES J.S. Macreedy notes the inscription with a sort of wry bemusement. He walks on, reaching the facade of the weather-beaten hotel. A gust of wind swirls down the street, momentarily engulfing Macreedy and the entire area in a sudden eddying whirlpool. As it subsides...

direction.raw_text: As he peers through the dust toward the dingy hotel. It has a narrow stoop and outsize bay windows on each side. Macreedy mounts the hotel steps. At the top of the steps Coley Trimble and Hector David watch him silently. Hector is large and leanly muscular, yet Coley looms over him like a battleship. He is a gross behemoth of a man, with sharp flinty eyes the size of glistening pinpoints and a slack, oversized jaw. Both men wear modern Western work clothes, but there is one incongruous accessory which Hector affects. Around his thick wrist is a watch with a large flat face and an elaborately tooled leather strap -- a cheap reproduction of one of those expensive Swiss timepieces which, among many distinguished accomplishments, tells the day of the week, the month of the year, the phase of the moon, etc., etc.

Macreedy is waiting at the empty desk as Hector strolls in, flopping his enormous bulk into a nicked and mothy chair. He picks up a newspaper, but his eyes remain on Macreedy. Macreedy waits patiently for the absent clerk. For a moment, he studies the open registration ledger; his eyes rove from the ink-splotched blotter up over the desk to one of those World War II banners, the imitation silk now stained and faded. direction.raw_text: DAY - MACREEDY in a new bathrobe, before a cracked, discolored mirror. He draws a safety razor down his face, completing his shave; then he wipes a hand over the mirror, which clouds with steam almost as fast as he can clear it. o.s., the SOUND of bath water gurgling down the tub drain. He runs a tentative finger inside the collar of his robe, pulling loose a price tag. He drops it carefully into a wastebasket. He turns on the faucet at the sink to rinse his shaving brush. The rusty pipes cough and rumble, roaring as a trickle of water arrives while the drain sucks loudly at its departure. He dries the razor, turns off the faucet and exits.

He stops outside a door, pushes the towel from his head to his neck and puts his hand on the knob. He is about to insert the key when he tenses. Slowly, silently, he turns the knob and throws open the door.

On the bed sprawls Hector David, his gigantic body straining the springs. He lies on his back, hands clasped easily under his head, thick legs crossed, his Stetson tilted over his low forehead. He is completely unconcerned by Macreedy's entrance. For a moment Macreedy stares at him. Then...

direction.raw_text: As Macreedy walks down hotel steps, a station wagon pulls up just before him. Tied with a rope to the right front fender is a magnificent eight-point buck. A stain of dry blood weaves an uneven course down his glossy flank from an unmistakable bullet hole in his shoulder. Two men get out of the car; one of them is Coley Trimble. He sees Macreedy coming toward him. He stands motionless in the center of the narrow pavement, picking at his nose with the detachment of a child. The other man is broad and excessively masculine as he swings out from behind the wheel. He walks around the car, joining Coley at the curb. Macreedy comes on. The man with Coley looks at the stranger with colossal indifference, as expressionless as the soil of Black Rock. His handsome face, under a dusty hunting cap, is taut and hard and wind-shaven. Next to Coley he stands motionless, except for the wisp of smoke from a black Cuban cigarette between his thin lips. In b.g., the loafers who had been ensconced in the hotel lobby move out the door and stand on the porch. They watch Macreedy, Coley and Reno Smith, the handsome, taut-faced man. Silence soems to settle over everything. It is Macreedy who breaks it...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gently he walks around Coley and Reno Smith and continues down the street. Coley's eyes follow him. Smith goes up the steps of the hotel and enters the lobby. Coley quickly follows him. The loafers on the porch go back inside.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (grinning wearily at Coley) Here we go again.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The loafers resume their familiar places as Smith walks briskly to the clerk's desk. Pete, in anticipation, opens the hotel register, places it before Smith
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Smith doesn't answer; he looks up thoughtfully. His eyes harden almost imperceptibly as he sees Coley, across the narrow room, looking out the window after Macreedy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Coley sits in the nearest chair. Beyond Smith, still resting easily against the high counter of Pete's desk, the gigantic figure of Hector appears at the top of the stairs. He comes down and joins Smith.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He hesitates as Doc Velie sidles amiably into earshot.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Smith looks thoughtfully out the window.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (deferentially, gesturing toward the open register) That's all I know about him, Mr. Smith.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Coley's back) Sit down.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (spinning to face him) I was only...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (interrupting) Sit down.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (after a pause) Pretty cool guy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Doesn't push easy?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (frowning) That's it -- that's just it. He pushes too easy. Maybe we oughtta...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What do you want, Doc?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nothing. (archly) I was just wondering what all you people were worrying about. (Smith looks at him coldly) Not that I have the slightest idea.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You wonder too much, and you talk too much. (pauses) It's a bad parlay, Doc.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I hold no truck with silence. (impishly) I got nothing to hide.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (suddenly towering over Doc) What're you tryin' to say?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nothing, man. It's just, you worry about the stranger only if you look at him... (slowly) ...from a certain aspect.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How do you look at him, Doc?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (firmly) With the innocence of a fresh-laid egg.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (after a pause) Keep it up, Doc. Be funny. Make bad jokes. (he starts to walk toward the window, Doc and Hector following him) And some day I'll have Coley wash out your mouth with lye.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Macreedy, down the end of the block, saunters easily up to Liz's garage.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The garage, without a door, opens on the street. Against the front of the building is parked a battered bicycle. On one of the barnlike walls a boy of nine is drawing laboriously with a piece of chalk. He puts the last flourish to a skull and crossbones identical with that seen earlier on the window of the equipment yard office. Macreedy stops a few feet from him, waiting until the boy prints "T.J.". As he steps back to admire his handiwork...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: T.J. nods. He approaches the wall, raising his chalk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He pauses. As Macreedy opens his mouth to interrogate further... T.J. Lady runs this garage. Again a pause. T.J. has just completed the final letter of the word "HATES". And again as Macreedy opens his mouth... T.J. She's not here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Again the pause. T.J. steps back, having completed his work, which, of course, broadcasts the fact that "T.J. HATES J.S.". And again as Macreedy begins to speak... T.J. In about ten minutes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: T.J. turns, pulls the bike away from the building, completes a fastidious "pony express" and peddles furiously out of scene.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hi, T.J.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This your garage? T.J. Nope.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (a beat) Where's the man it belongs to? T.J. Ain't a man.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where'd she go? T.J. (shrugging) I dunno. Somewhere.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: When will she be back? T.J. I dunno. Sometime.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (with a grin) Thanks.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: as Macreedy, after a moment's hesitation, starts down it. From the far end, at the telegraph agent's shack, a figure starts running toward Macreedy. It is Hastings. INTERCUT between the two men. Hastings, in his concentration, doesn't see the stranger until he is almost upon him. He slows down, suddenly, awkwardly, to a self-conscious walk. Macreedy grins at him, passes on, shaking his head speculatively. Hastings, with a parting glance, gallops up the hotel steps.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Smith, Coley, Hector, Pete, Doc, Sam et al are still in evidence. Smith is in a tight little group at the desk with Coley, Hector and Pete. Doc has taken a position at the window, looking out. Hastings bursts in and half-runs to Smith...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: FAVORING SMITH AND HASTINGS as the excited telegraph agent speaks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Smith ignores him, thinking. Hastings breathes heavily. Finally...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hastings nods, scribbling on a pad.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hastings nods and hurriedly exits.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Smith looks at Coley, trying to decide if the question in any way challenges his authority. He concludes not...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pete nods, his brow furrowed uncomfortably in a frown.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: At this point the brittle silence is cracked by...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Smith and those around him look off in the direction of Doc.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I called the Circle T. He ain't got business there -- not if they don't know him. Right, Mr. Smith?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Hastings) Send a wire to Nick Gandi in Los Angeles. Tell him to find out all he can about John J. Macreedy. Tell him I want to know fast. Sign my name.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What was that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nick Gandi. G-A-N-D-I. Care of the Blake Hotel.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (after a beat) Who's Gandi?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's a private detective. (beat) I drive to L.A. now and then.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (slightly worried) He'll get us the dope?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He'll get us anything, for twenty bucks a day and expenses. (Hector frowns) Hector, you worry too fast and too easy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's just, I don't like it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Maybe he's just passing through.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't bet on it. He can only mean trouble.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (smiles faintly) Hector, you're jumpy as a stall horse.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (doggedly) We oughtta see him... talk to him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (quietly) About what? (Hector doesn't answer) What'll we talk to him about? The birds, the bees? The weather? The crops? (pauses) You tried -- where'd it get you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (uncomfortably) I only thought...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sure. You only thought.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (after a beat) What do we do?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What do you do? You wait. Like Pete here. Right, Pete?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's all you do. But while you wait... I talk to him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (o.s.) Hey!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - AT THE WINDOW peering out. He turns in the direction of Smith and the others.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Smith goes to the window, edging Doc to one side with a shoulder. He looks out grimly.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Now what do you know? (beaming) Mr. Macreedy seems to be heading for the jail. (impishly) Now what do you suppose he'd want to see the Sheriff about?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Macreedy, down the street, cuts up the steps of the jail.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Smith staring out the window with a frown. Doc watching him out of the corner of his eye, a bemused expression crossing his puckish features.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sequence omitted from original script.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . JAIL ANGLE on Macreedy as he enters the jail. It is small and dirty, with only a tired desk, two chairs and the usual police posters on the wall. One side leads to the cell block and Macreedy heads for it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: from interior of cell block comprising two cells, both of which are open. A man is asleep in the lower bunk of the front cell. The keys are in the lock. Macreedy shakes his head and starts to close the creaking cell door. Sheriff TIM HORN, the man in the bunk, lifts his head, blinking his bleary eyes. He is in terrible shape.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He manages to crawl off the bunk and out toward Macreedy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He walks out of the cell, Macreedy following him into the office.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hold it, friend.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (grinning) I ain't hankerin' to get locked in my own jail.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sorry. I thought you were a guest.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: As it happens, I'm the host.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - OF THE TWO Tim breaks out a bottle of booze, starts to take a snort, then stops, offers it to Macreedy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He takes a belt that would incapacitate half the county. He finishes, smacks his lips, lays the bottle down, and falls into a chair. He looks up at Macreedy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tim studies him, trying to focus.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Macreedy starts to say something, then stops. Reconsidering...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Sheriff reaches for his bottle. In his haste he drops it. Macreedy's hand moves quickly, catching the bottle before it hits the floor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: For a moment heavy silence. Finally...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Macreedy grins harshly and exits. Tim watches him go, then slowly reaches for the bottle. He pauses, looks at his shaking hand. Then he withdraws it and just sits in the chair staring blindly ahead, seeing nothing.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Snort?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, thanks.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't blame you. It's awful.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (suddenly mean) What're you lookin' at?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (easy) You tell me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (after a beat, relaxing) I ain't always this bad -- just that last night me and my pal Doc Velie, we did a little celebratin'. At least I did.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What were you celebrating?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (shrugs) You name it. (studies Macreedy) What do you want?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My name's Macreedy. I came in on the Streamliner.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You what?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I said I came in...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (interrupting) You ain't from around here. Up Tucson way -- Phoenix? Mesa? You ain't sellin' cattle nor seed nor nothin' like that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No. (sighs, then distinctly as to a child) All I want from you is a little information. I've got to get to a place called Adobe Flat.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (reacts; then, tight- lipped) This ain't no information bureau.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: One thing about Black Rock -- everybody's polite. Makes for gracious living.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nobody asked you here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How do you know? (he moves toward the door, with a rueful grin)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (starting after him) What about Adobe Flat?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm looking for a man named Komako.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Almost a disaster.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (sinking back in his chair) A fate worse'n death. (he takes the bottle from Macreedy) You move fast for a crip... for a big man.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What about Komako?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (slowly) If there's no further questions...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Frowning, deep in thought, Macreedy walks down the dusty street. As he reaches the hotel...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Macreedy stops, looks toward Smith as he walks out to meet him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As Smith joins him, he walks on. Smith falls in step beside him. GO WITH THEM.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: At this point they are in front of...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (o.s.) Mr. Macreedy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's the friendliest word I've heard since I got here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (grins boyishly) My name is Smith. I own the Triple- Bar ranch. (holds out his hand; Macreedy shakes it) I want to apologize for some of the folks in town.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They act like they're sitting on a keg.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A keg...? Of what?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know. Maybe diamonds. Maybe gunpowder.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (disarmingly) No. Nothing like that. We're a little suspicious of strangers is all. Hangover from the old days. The old West.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I thought the tradition of the old West was hospitality.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (with a sincere smile) I'm trying to be hospitable, Mr. Macreedy. (boyishly pushes his dusty cap back on his head) Going to be around for a while?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Could be.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How would you like to go hunting tomorrow? I'd be proud to have you as my guest.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thanks, but I'm afraid not.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (with admirable candor) You mean, because of your arm? (slaps Macreedy's shoulder in a friendly, understanding gesture) I knew a man once, lost an arm in a threshing accident. Used to hunt all the time. (almost too blandly) But he was quite a man. He... (pauses; then, with discreet and charming gravity) I'm sorry. I... What I mean is -- if there's anything I can do while you're around...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm looking for... (sighs) Never mind. Thanks, anyway.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (quietly) You're looking for what, Mr. Macreedy?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (eyeing him) A man named Komako.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (no hesitation) Komako -- Sure, I remember him -- Japanese farmer. Never had a chance.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He got here in '41 -- just before Pearl Harbor. Three months later he was shipped to one of those relocation centers. (shaking his head) Tough.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Which one did he go to?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who knows?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You think maybe if I wrote him, the letter would be forwarded?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm sure it would. Write your letter. I'll see it gets out tonight.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It wouldn't be too much trouble?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No trouble at all.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Funny. Because I think it would be a great deal of trouble for you. It's been a great deal of trouble for me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Macreedy stops, as does Smith. He looks keenly at Smith as he takes from his inner jacket pocket a half-dozen letters...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Smith opens his mouth to reply when the NOISE of a jeep o.s. interrupts him. The jeep comes INTO SHOT. Liz Brooks, at the wheel, cuts the engine and jumps out. Smith ambles silently to a wall and leans against it. Liz reaches behind the driver's seat and hoists, with both hands and some effort, a five-gallon drum of axle grease from the floor of the jeep. As she rests it on the rear fender...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The girl looks at Smith, who has made no attempt to help her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She lifts the drum to the ground.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Liz looks from Smith to Macreedy, puzzled.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Liz hesitates. Macreedy notes her confusion as her eyes seek Smith's for instructions. Quickly he moves in...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Macreedy hands her a bill. She fumbles with it, not knowing what else to do. Her eyes drift to Macreedy's stiff arm...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He steps toward the jeep as...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He steps into jeep and, with one hand expertly manipulating the controls, drives off.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I wrote these letters to Komako. They weren't forwarded. They were returned -- address unknown. (he smiles grimly at Smith) So I guess there's nothing you can do for me, after all.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (going to her) Need a little help?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I can manage.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, I need a little help. (she looks at him questioningly) I'd like to rent your jeep.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It'll be two dollars an hour, gas extra, and ten dollars for my time.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Liz) Aren't you going to ask him where he wants to go?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He wants to go to Adobe Flat.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The road's marked?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (nodding) Yeah. It's about six -- seven miles down...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then I won't need your time.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (uneasily) I thought you might... need a little help.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I can manage.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Liz. Do you have a license to rent cars? You could get into trouble.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's all right. I won't mention it to the Sheriff.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Smith turns his attention to the girl...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: For a moment Smith doesn't answer. Instead, with a half frown, he lifts the bill Macreedy had given her from Liz's hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He crumples it, pokes the wad in her hand and walks off down the street as...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (slowly) You shouldn't have done that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I thought it would be better if he went out there and got done with it. (Smith looks at her sharply) I mean, what could he find out?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (as he studies it) This is liable to be the hardest ten dollars you ever earned in your life.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Sequence omitted from original script.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tim sits in his chair, still staring sightlessly at the whiskey bottle. Smith enters. He looks from Tim to the bottle on the table, then back to Tim.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He stares harshly at the Sheriff. Tim tries unsuccessfully to meet his gaze. Then, slowly, he sits down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Smith slowly walks behind Tim's chair and silently, patronizingly pats the Sheriff's slack shoulder...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (after a beat, disinterestedly) What did he want -- the stranger?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (abstractedly) He asked about Komako. (looking up at Smith) You think he'll kick up a storm?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (easily) A storm? About what?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know. All I know, I don't want trouble around here. (pauses awkwardly, then) Never again.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Trouble? You don't know anything about Komako, now do you, Tim?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I do not. That's the point.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The point is, what you don't know can't hurt you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Maybe there's something I ought to know. Maybe I ought to ask you... before the stranger comes back and starts breathing down my neck.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (a faint smile) Tim, you're a lost ball in the high weeds. I told you a long time ago, nothing happened for you to worry about.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (stands up, facing Smith) Thing is, I do worry. Maybe I ain't much else, but I'm sure a worrier. (beat, then with soft emphasis) And I'm still the law.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then do your job, Tim.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What is my job, Mr. Smith? Maybe I'd better find out before Macreedy does it for me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (evenly) Macreedy'll do nothing, Tim. And neither will you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Suppose I decide to try?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That would be dangerous. You got the body of a hippo, Tim, but the brain of a rabbit. Don't overtax it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (lowering his eyes, mumbling) Yes, Mr. Smith.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Hastings is sitting at his desk. The telegraph ticker starts to splutter. Hastings rushes to it. He listens, and starts to scribble. Then he gulps nervously, a confused expression on his face. As the telegraph key stops as suddenly as it had begun, Hastings jumps up frantically and, holding the sheet of paper, runs out of the shack.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: as he runs toward hotel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: with Doc, Sam, Coley, Hector and Pete on the porch. Hastings runs up the steps, pausing momentarily. His jaws move, but CAMERA is too far away to pick up his obvious question. Coley gestures toward the jail; then Hastings turns and runs down the steps followed by Doc et al.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hastings runs down the street toward the jail followed by Doc et al.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: as Hastings runs up the steps with a hobnailed clatter. Smith comes out to investigate, followed by Tim. Doc, et al are congregated at the foot of the steps. Hastings slaps the sheet of paper in front of Smith. Utter quiet. Everyone stares at Smith, waiting for a reaction -- everyone except Tim, who stares straight ahead, seeing nothing, and Doc, whose eyes are locked sympathetically on Tim. Smith finishes reading the wire. His face is expressionless. After a moment...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Smith doesn't answer but...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He folds the message carefully, puts it in his pocket. Abruptly Tim turns and disappears inside his office. Smith, with some restraint, walks down the steps to the street.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (to Smith) From L.A.?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah! From that private detective!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Smith) What does he say? Who is this guy?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Never heard of him, that's what he says! He checked and there's no John J. Macreedy. No listing -- no record -- no information. Nothing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (quietly, after a beat, to Smith) Where does that leave us?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll tell you where...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Shut up!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: as he takes Coley's arm, and Pete's. The trio moves away, taking a position perhaps 15 feet from Doc. Hector, Sam and Hastings move toward them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sequence omitted from original script.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In b.g. at a respectful distance are Hector, Sam and Hastings. SHOOT parallel to tracks, which disappear far into the horizon. The following dialogue is delivered in an undertone...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Coley is terribly preoccupied, balances himself, like a child, on a steel rail.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Brittle silence for a moment. Then...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pete doesn't answer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pete is silent.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There is a long, electric silence. Pete is defeated.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He pauses for emphasis. Then, as he starts to talk again...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (turning to Coley) Now, Coley...?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (takes a breath, then) I think Macreedy's a nothing. A nobody.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Is he?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So there's nothing to worry about.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Isn't there? (a beat) You got brains, you have.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (squirming) But what can he find out? That Komako was...? (Smith glares at him) Suppose he finds out?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A nobody like Macreedy can raise a pretty big stink. The point is... who would miss a nobody like Macreedy if he just, say, disappeared? Who, Coley?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (exasperated) Coley!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (galvanized from the rail) Huh?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why don't we wait...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Wait for what?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I mean, maybe he won't find anything. Maybe he'll just go away.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not Macreedy. I know those maimed guys. Their minds get twisted. They put on hair shirts and act like martyrs. They're all of 'em do- gooders, trouble makers, freaks.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But there's no danger yet. Let's wait and see.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (interrupting, appealing to Coley as an equal) No danger, he says. This guy's like a carrier of small pox. Since he arrives, there's been a fever in this town, an infection. And it's spreading. (he glances from Coley to Pete) Hastings has been in a sick sweat, running around, shooting off his face. Doc, for the first time in four years, gets snotty with me. Liz... (to Pete) ...your own sister -- acts like a fool.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (hotly) She's just a kid.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (scoffing) Kid! She must have strained every muscle in her head to get so stupid! Renting him a jeep! And Tim -- Tim, the rum-dum. Tim suddenly decides he's gotta act like a Sheriff. (to Coley, gesturing at Pete) And he says what's the danger.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (easily) Of course, if you want to take the chance...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (grimly) Not me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All right, then...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's not all right! You're so mighty quick to kill -- he's not an animal!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Coley, with mock surprise) Well, listen to little spitfire... (turning slowly on Pete) You sniveling toad! I'm saving your neck! If I don't, who will?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (squirming) All I said...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who will?! Doc? Tim? Your sister, with the rocks in her head?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: One thing about your sister -- she's got twice the guts you have. You're only fit for running away.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's too late for that. (belligerently, slowly, at Pete) He's in this, and he ain't running no place.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (finally) All right, then...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Tim stands facing the wall, shoulders hunched, suffering. Doc comes in and watches him silently, Tim turns, facing Doc, turns again to concentrate on a faded newspaper photograph framed and hanging on the wall.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: DEPUTY SHERIFF NAMED FOR BLACK ROCK

direction.raw_text: over his shoulder. Focal point: the "photograph". It shows a widly grinning, moderately alert and healthy Tim of perhaps five years ago. He is wearing, proudly, his badge of office, and behind him, mildly interested in the proceedings, is Reno Smith, his erstwhile sponsor. The heading on the photo reads: DEPUTY SHERIFF NAMED FOR BLACK ROCK.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tim takes the photo off the wall and, holding it, turns to face Doc...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Doc squirms but doesn't answer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tim takes off his badge and throws it on the desk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They look at each other. Slowly Tim picks up his badge and pins it back on.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Let Smith find himself a new boy. I can't take it another day. (pauses, looks at Doc) If you're a sheriff, they gotta respect you, otherwise you can't do your job. (shakes his head) They just laugh.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't laugh, Tim.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why don't you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Cut it out, Tim.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You should!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: In the name of well-adjusted manhood, snap out of it. You're going to get a complex or something.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Four years ago if I'd of done my job... if I'd of checked up and found out what happened. But I didn't! Just like Smith figured.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What could you have found out? They told you a story. You had to believe it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do you believe it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do you know what happened?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know. (ironically) I lead a quiet, contemplative life.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Me, I didn't even try to find out. (a beat) Don't you understand? (he taps the badge on his chest) When you wear that badge, you're the Law. And when something happens, against the Law, you're supposed to do something about it. It's your job. (simply) Me... I did nothin'. And that's what's eatin' me. What kind of prescription you got for that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know. I've never been able to find one for myself.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Only one thing -- don't quit, Tim.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why not?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Maybe this feller Macreedy has the prescription.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Sequence omitted from original script.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: An old marker, jutting on an angle at the side of the road, reads: ADOBE FLAT. Beneath it an arrow points ahead. Macreedy steers the jeep up the narrow, rutted trail between a serious of enormous boulders.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: as he drives to the far end of the boulders, reaching a flat piece of land completely surrounded by rocks. Beyond the rocks is what remains of a burned-out ranch house, and an abandoned well.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sequence omitted from original script.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: in the wreckage. The remains of an iron bed. The burned-out shell of a pick-up truck. Part of a stove. A morass of bottles, all sizes and shapes, some of them broken. Macreedy halts momentarily beside the well. Reaching out he touches the warped sun-beaten boards that cover the mouth. He removes one, and, picking up a pebble, drops it through the opening. There is a long beat and then, from far, far below we HEAR a faint PLUNK (o.s.). He replaces the board and walks to a broken wall. He touches the burned out frame of a picture. The frame falls to the ground, leaving an un-scorched square on the surface of the wall. He goes past a solitary standing stone chimney. Suddenly he halts, arrested by something among the rubble, the rottenness and the ashes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Surrounded by the seared and blackened earth is a rectangular patch of lovely wild flowers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: studying the brightly colored flowers. His face is lined in thought. He stoops, gathers a few buds in his hand. He examines them, his brow furrowed. As he slowly twirls a flower between thumb and forefinger, CAMERA PANS from Macreedy in a long slow arc, taking in miles and miles of barren wasteland. CAMERA RISES, TILTING UPWARD to a cliff far away and shielded from Macreedy's view by the intervening rocks and ridges.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: and on it the outline of an automobile.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: empty. It is parked on a narrow dirt road. On one side of the road the cliff falls abruptly to the valley far below; on the other, the steep, shaly outcropping continues to rise. For a moment CAMERA HOLDS on the car. Then it PANS SLOWLY upward about fifty feet, HOLDING this time on...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: where a man is looking off toward Adobe Flat through a pair of high-powered glasses. The man is Coley Trimble.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - MACREEDY Grimly he walks toward the jeep, still holding the wild flowers. Now he pockets them, jumps into the vehicle and drives off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - COLEY continues to train his glasses on Macreedy far below in the moving jeep.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - MACREEDY driving steadily over rough, rocky terrain.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: climbs down from the pinnacle of the cliff and enters a big, powerful '36 Packard sedan.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: shifts to low gear as the jeep presses into hilly country.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - IN HIS CAR turns on the ignition.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - IN THE JEEP as it winds along a road with the cliff rising on one side and falling off steeply on the other. He rounds a curve, passes an insignificant side road, drives on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The car with Coley at the wheel pulls out, follows Macreedy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: between the two cars, with the distance between them constantly diminishing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sequence omitted from original script.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: a straightaway, cutting through rocky outcroppings on both sides. Macreedy's jeep roars by, pursued by the gaining Packard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - (PROCESS) For the first time he is aware that he is being followed, and that the man at the wheel of the big Packard is Coley.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - PACKARD picking up tremendous speed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: proceeding over a series of turns, inclines, declivities (according to location terrain). Engines roar, brakes whinny, tires scream, skidding on the turns.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: as Coley overtakes Macreedy. He steers the big car within a foot or two of the jeep. The terrain has steepened; on the right there is nothing between the road and the valley floor far below but a few inches of soft shoulder. As Macreedy pulls wide on a razor turn, Coley tries to come inside him. Macreedy, fighting for control of the veering jeep, succeeds in cutting him off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In the approach, Coley cuts sharp into the jeep. The jeep seems to roll with the blow, then leaps ahead, maneuvering the turn.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: COLEY IN CAR (PROCESS) Coley is flustered, his face blood-shot with fury. He seems to generate an atmosphere of vicious, cruel craziness; the wild smile across his mouth is almost sensual, obscene. He floorboards the Packard. Like some monstrous battering ram, the heavy car smashes into the jeep's rear bumper, kicking the smaller vehicle jerkily ahead. Coley floorboards the gas pedal, again. Each time he slams into the jeep with sickening force, with the brutal abrasion of metal pounding metal.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - (PROCESS) With one arm he works frantically to keep his under-sized car on the twisty road. He sees ahead a precipitous cliff falling off on an impossibly sharp curve. He makes a decision... Just ahead the gradient is comparatively gradual, however steep by normal standards. He swings the jeep off the road, onto the declivity. The car plunges downward, miraculously upright. Macreedy jockeys it to a whirring, shuddering halt in the soft sand at the bottom of a draw. Macreedy turns slightly and looks up the mountain-side with the road at its summit...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : EXTREME LONG SHOT - COLEY standing at the edge of the road, peering down at him. In b.g., the Packard. Coley turns emphatically, gets into car, drives off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: His face is caked with the sweat of his exertions and dust kicked up by the grinding wheels. He exhales heavily and runs a shaky hand across the side of his head. He becomes aware suddenly of a NOISE, a trickling, an unmistakable tinkle as of running water. He frowns, opens the jeep door...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: as Macreedy unlatches the hood and throws it open. The NOISE continues. Macreedy examines the engine and finds the difficulty...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: focal point: the nut joining the gas line with the carburetor has worked loose in the jouncing the car has taken. With his hand Macreedy screws it tight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: as Macreedy lowers the hood, re-enters jeep. He turns on ignition. The engine fires. As he drives slowly out of the ravine...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: his long face even more horsey than usual, with half an apple in his mouth. He stands in front of the grocery store, with the baskets of fruit on the sidewalk. He looks up, stops crunching.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: at the window of the Bar & Grill, cleaning an ear with a toothpick. He looks out. The toothpick is motionless.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: fidgeting outside his shack. He looks up. His Adam's apple turns completely over.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sequence omitted from original script.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Macreedy slowly driving the jeep toward Liz's garage. He looks neither to the right nor left.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Standing on the porch of the hotel, watching. Smith's face compresses, and his eyes swivel to rest on Coley's with cold, contemptuous anger. Coley licks his lips uneasily. Smith turns and enters the hotel. Coley meekly follows.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He brakes the jeep before the garage. No one is there. He parks the vehicle, gets out and heads down the street.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Macreedy is about to go up the steps when he sees Coley's car at the curb. Both right fenders are creased. An ugly, jagged break has split the front bumper almost in half, one part angling crazily toward the sky, the other drooping in the dust of the road. Smith and Coley come out of the hotel. They stand on the porch, watching Macreedy as he in turn watches the car. They exchange a glance. Smith nods, so...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He walks down the steps to the street, joining Macreedy. Smith remains on the porch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He walks up the steps, past Smith, and into the hotel. Coley glances up at Smith, grinning with self-satisfaction, like a small boy who has carried out perfectly the instructions of his teacher.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Well, if it's not Macreedy - the world's champion road hog.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah. It's a small world.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But such an unfriendly one. Now why did you want to crowd me off the road?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (with a slow grin) I'm kind of sorry if I've incurred your displeasure.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Look what you did to my car.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If there's anything I can do to make up for it...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You ought to be careful, man -- all that one-arm driving.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'd be glad to pay the damages.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's a threat to life and limb.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Fortunately no one was hurt.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You could get yourself killed that way -- nosin' all over the countryside.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's the real danger, I can see that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why that's pretty smart of you. How long you intend to keep it up?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm getting out of here, right now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The lobby empty except for Pete behind the desk. Macreedy goes to him. Pete seems elaborately occupied arranging and re-arranging a few file cards. Smith enters the lobby. He stands in b.g. watching Macreedy and the desk clerk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He turns, walks toward porch. Pete looks at Smith. Smith's eyes follow Macreedy.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (to Pete) Still expecting that convention?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (looking up) What...?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If you're expecting any extra cowboys, my room is available.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're checking out?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (nodding) Is there a train through here tonight?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nothing till tomorrow morning. The streamliner.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know that. How about freights? (Pete shakes his head) Milk train?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Tomorrow. After the streamliner.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Busses?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Closest stop is Sand City -- thirty- two miles away. (a beat) You're in such a hurry, you should have never got off here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm inclined to agree with you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Sequence omitted from original script.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In the gloom of the lube pit, Liz's mechanic, a dirty old man, is draining the oil out of the crankcase of the car on the rack. The girl stands beside the pit, silently watching the old man. Now she pauses, looks o.s. toward the open garage doors...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: entering the scene, stopping to look at Liz's jeep parked in front of the wide doors. He turns his eyes vaguely in the direction of Liz, but he doesn't see her in the shadows behind the car on the rack, He advances a step, pausing...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Anybody home?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Sequence omitted from original script.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She does not answer. Instead, she silently twists the crankcase petcock, stopping the flow of oil. She watches Macreedy closely.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Macreedy again shifts his eyes to the jeep, then, with decision, he goes to a work bench, opening the drawers and rummaging among the contents.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Macreedy turns as Liz comes toward him. She gestures toward the open drawers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Macreedy waits for her to go on. She doesn't. She stands there, staring at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She turns, walks back toward the lube pit.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She doesn't answer. Macreedy goes to her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She opens her mouth to answer, but she doesn't know what to say.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He waits as she tries to answer, and again she can't. For a moment he watches her struggle in anguished silence with herself. Then he turns and goes out.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (o.s.) If you're looking for the jeep key...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...it's not there...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (after a beat) In that case, where do you suggest I look?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (over her shoulders) The jeep's not for rent.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It was, just a few hours ago.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (flatly) Things change.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (with grim amusement) Sure. And Smith is the kid who changes 'em.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Miss Brooks. (softly) What's the matter with this town of yours?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nothing. It's none of your concern.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then why are they all so concerned about me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Am I concerned?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, you're not. But...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But what?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (easily) But it strikes me you're a little too unconcerned. So unconcerned you won't even rent me a jeep.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (flaring) I don't run a taxi service. I don't have a license.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I wish others in this town were as scrupulously devoted to law and order as you are.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (hotly) Why don't you lay off! If you don't like it here, go back where you came from!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Funny thing. They try to kill me, and you feel persecuted.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't want to get involved.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Involved in what?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (retreating) Whatever you're up to. Whatever happens, I've got to go on living here. These people are my neighbors, my friends.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All of them?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (slowly) This is my town, Mr. Macreedy, like it or not. Whatever happened here, it was long ago, now it's... it's...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (evenly) Dead and buried? (a beat) Whatever did happen, you don't seem to like it. Why do you stick around?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (after a beat) Because of my brother. Pete. He'd never leave.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Didn't you ever think of going without him. You're sort of independent and he's... he's...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Weak. I know. That's why I couldn't leave him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (softly) What did your brother do?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He... I... (flaring again) What do you care? What do you care about Black Rock?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nothing much. Only, there're not many places like this in America -- but even one is too many. Because I think something sort of bad happened here. (frowning) Something I can't find the handle to...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You just think so. You don't know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This much I know -- the rule of law has been suspended in this town. The gorillas have taken over.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're a fine one to talk! You come in here, sneaking around, trying to steal the key to my jeep.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I kind of had a notion that was the only way I could get it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (simply) Was I wrong, Miss Brooks?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: walks thoughtfully down street. He comes abreast of hotel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: where Smith is still sitting. For a moment he watches Macreedy speculatively, then...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He stands facing Smith on the porch, then...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He takes the other chair.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Smith laughs quietly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Macreedy laughs quietly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He takes the wild flowers from his pocket, holding them in front of Smith.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Macreedy gets up, half turns to Smith.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He starts down the steps.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He turns and walks down the street.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (calling) Mr. Macreedy. (reasonably, as Macreedy turns toward him) I'd like to ask you a few questions... as long as you're around...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (walking up steps) I'm around all right.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (with just a touch of wryness) You probably know that Miss Brooks is no longer in the car rental business?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (solemnly) Good. I wouldn't want to see that girl get into trouble...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You wouldn't?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...what with rental permits, gas rationing... you know what I mean.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sure. I admire your sturdy sense of responsibility.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (dismissively) It's just, a girl like that has a future.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Let's talk about my future.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (almost slyly) Do you have the time?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't seem to be going any place.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (after a pause) I hear you handle a jeep real well.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I have a way with jeeps. A certain familiarity.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I think I understand. You're an Army man. (looking at Macreedy's stiff arm) Where'd you get it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Italy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (sincerely) Tough. I tried to get in myself, the day after those rats bombed Pearl Harbor.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What stopped you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The physical. They wouldn't take me. The morning after Pearl, I was the first man in line at Marine recruiting in Sand City. And they wouldn't take me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (flatly) Tough.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What do you do in Los Angeles, Mr. Macreedy?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm retired.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're a pretty young man...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You might say I was forced into retirement.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What were you looking for in Adobe Flat?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Komako, like I told you. Like you told me, he wasn't there.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's so funny?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nothing. It's just -- I don't believe you. I believe a man is as big as what he seeks. I believe you're a big man, Mr. Macreedy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Flattery will get you nowhere.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why would a man like you be looking for a lousy Jap farmer?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Maybe I'm not so big.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, you are. (a beat; looking hard at Macreedy) I believe that a man is as big as the things that make him mad. Nobody around here has been big enough to make you mad.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What makes you mad, Mr. Smith?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Me...? Nothing in particular.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (bemused) I see. You're a big man, too. Only... (calmly) ...the Japanese make you mad...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's different. After the sneak attack on Pearl Harbor... after Bataan...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...and Komako made you mad.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's the same thing. (scoffing) Loyal Japanese-Americans -- that's a laugh. They're mad dogs. Look at Corregidor, the death march.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What did Komako have to do with Corregidor?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Wasn't he a Jap? Look, Macreedy, there's a law in this county against shooting dogs. But if I see a mad dog loose, I don't wait for him to bite me. (exhales sharply, shaking his head with irritation) I swear, you're beginning to make me mad.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (calmly) All strangers do.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not all. Some of 'em. When they come here snooping.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Snooping for what?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I mean, outsiders coming around, looking for something.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (pressing) For what?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know. People are always looking for something in this part of the West. To the historian, it's the "Old West." To the book writers, it's the "Wild West." To the businessmen, it's the "Undeveloped West." They all say we're backward and poor, and I guess we are. (snorts) We don't even have enough water. (a beat) But this place, to us, is our West. (heatedly) I just wish they'd leave us alone.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Leave you alone to do what?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (coldly) I don't know what you mean.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What happened to Komako?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He went away, I told you. Shortly after he left, a bunch of kids got fooling around out his place. They burned it down. It was one of those things -- you know how kids are.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's funny?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nothing. Only -- I don't believe you. Any more than I believed you about the letters.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (smiling) You don't seem to believe anything I say.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (vaguely) Yes, I do -- about businessmen, for instance. I think a businessman would be interested in Adobe Flat.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All that land lying fallow. Could be put to some use. Like a graveyard. (Smith opens his mouth to speak but Macreedy goes on) A historian might be interested, too. Because of the strange customs around here, such as burying cattle...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Burying cattle...?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (calmly) Something's buried out there.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: See these wild flowers? That means a grave. I've seen it overseas. I figure it isn't a man's grave or someone would have marked it. Sort of a mystery, isn't it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sort of. Maybe you can figure it out.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Maybe.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why not give it a whirl? (Macreedy turns) It'll help you pass the time... (continued; meaningfully) ...for a while.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not interested. I got other things to do.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: headed towards Doc's establishment. The building, which serves Doc as home, office and laboratory, has centered on a pane of glass: T.R. VELIE, JR. UNDERTAKER AND VETERINARY And in the lower right hand corner:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A few of the peeled gold and black letters are completely missing. The building is separated from the structure next to it by an alleyway. Filling the narrow passage is Hector David, his long massive body wedged against the wall like an unkempt monument. His little pig eyes meet Macreedy's. Hector spits in the dust with bland insolence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: walks up the steps and enters.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dark and shadowy. At the far end of a hallway an insipid light bulb burns. Macreedy goes toward it, entering...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: devoted to the care and preservation of the Dear Departed. In the center of the room is a long rectangular slab stained with the juices of those unfortunates who have had occasion to rest thereon. The walls are lined with rickety bookcases jammed, not with volumes, but with the jugs and jars, the chemicals and unguents of Doc's multiple callings. In a corner three or four neat pine boxes are stacked one on the other. Doc sits at a cluttered desk feeding a large bowl of goldfish and sipping a glass of milk. He looks up as Macreedy enters.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Macreedy reaches for the phone book.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Macreedy thinks it over and comes to a swift decision. He checks the phone book. Then, picking up phone...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hi. Pull up a chair.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (nodding) Can I use your phone?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Help yourself. (chuckles) You know, you're one of the few people who's ever been back here I can say that to.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (pausing) What's 4-2-4?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If I've got you pegged -- and I think I have -- you're calling the State Police. But if I was you -- and I'm purely glad I'm not -- I'd look it up myself. (emphatically) I wouldn't trust anybody around here, including me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Doc) Thanks. (into receiver)
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: a cubbyhole behind the hotel clerk's desk in the lobby. At the switchboard is Pete, and above him tacked on the wall is the sign:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (into phone)
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: ...? (he looks up)
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: revealing Smith standing beside him. The two men exchange a nod.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (into phone) Lines 're busy. (he clicks off the instrument)
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Macreedy slowly puts down the phone. Doc sips his milk, all the while staring queasily over the glass at Macreedy. He puts it down, his gaze still fixed on the stranger...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He goes to a topographic map hanging on the wall -- a large, impressive map -- faded, fly-blown and divided into sections.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He moves to photograph beside the map on the wall -- a large, impressive photograph of a placer mine in operation.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He moves to his desk, picks up a glistening blob of stone, resting next to an assayer's scales, and examines it...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He bangs the rock down next to the scales.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He moves to a third illustration -- a colored reproduction, large and impressive -- of acres upon green acres of produce in bloom; the kind of picture Southern Pacific places above its calendars.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He moves to the coffins piled in a corner and runs his hand down the smooth pine sides with loving tenderness.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Doc nods; he points vaguely toward the street...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Macreedy snares the key and walks out. Doc gets up to follow him.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (sing-song) I know -- don't tell me -- lines all busy. They'll be busy all day.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (after a beat, grimacing) Don't look at me like that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Like what?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Like I'm a potential customer.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Everybody is -- and I get 'em coming and going.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (gesturing toward it) First I sell 'em a piece of land. Think they farm it? Nope. They dig for gold.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They rip off the top soil of ten winding hills. They sprint in here, fog-heaved with excitement, lugging nuggets, big and bright and shiny.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (rhetorically) Is it gold?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It is not! Do they quit? They do not!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (with theatrical gesture toward reproduction) Then they decide to farm. Farm! In country so dry you have to prime a man before he can spit, and before you can say "Fat Sam" they're stalled, stranded and starving. They get weevil- brained and buttsprung...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (simply) So I bury 'em. (a beat, as he rejoins Macreedy in the center of the room) But why should I bore you with my triumphs?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah. I've got a problem of my own.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (like an old testament prophet) They're going to kill you with no hard feelings.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (nastily) And you'll just sit on your hands and let them.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't get waspish with me, young feller.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sorry.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I feel for you, but I'm consumed with apathy. Why should I mix in?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: To save a life.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I got enough trouble saving my own. (he refills his glass from a milk bottle on the desk) I try to live right and drink my orange juice every day. But mostly I try to mind my own business. Which is something I'd advise you to do.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's a little late for that...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You can still get out of town. And you'd better get out like a whisper.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How can I?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (taking a key ring from his pocket) I got sort of a limousine at your disposal.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where is it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (tossing him the key) Out back.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: An old-fashioned hearse, with plate glass sides and elaborate lead candelabra -- Doc's "limousine" -- is parked a few steps from the door. Macreedy climbs in behind the wheel as Doc comes out and stands on the small back porch. Macreedy turns on the ignition switch. His foot kicks over the starter, but the spark doesn't catch. He tries again, then again. He pauses, frowns, as Doc comes down from the porch and joins him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Again he presses the ignition switch. Nothing. And suddenly, in b.g., the great bulk of Hector David looms up, leaning against the porch pillar at the corner of the alleyway. His expression is almost dreamy. For a moment he stands there while Macreedy toys with the ignition and the sick engine wheezes and grinds. Then he ambles up to the hearse...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Macreedy takes the cigarette, lighting a match with one hand. He puts the fire to Doc's smoke and then lights his own. He inhales, exhales, thinking. Finally... Macreedy gets out of the car. Hector has already opened the hood. Doc peers nervously over his shoulder. As they study the engine, Hector's horsey face appears behind them. He gestures toward the engine.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (concentrating on the dashboard) Won't start.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (nervously, to Macreedy) Something wrong?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Just won't start...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (gratuitously) Could be the wirin'. Why don't you look under the hood?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: For that I thank you. (pause) How much time you think I've got before...?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They'll wait at least till dark. (angrily) They'd be afraid to see each other's faces.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (slapping Doc's shoulder lightly) Well, so long, Doc. I can't say it's been charming but...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where are you going?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know. But I'm going on foot.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's no good. You stray ten yards off Main Street, and you'll be stone, cold dead. (offers Macreedy a cigarette) That's the situation, in a nut.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Focal point: a hopeless snarl of ignition wires.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's the wirin', like I said. Now wasn't that a good guess? Slowly he takes off his wrist watch and puts it in his pants pocket.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ignoring Hector, he bends over the engine, controlling his obvious awareness that Hector has fouled up the ignition.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hector's eyes go hard. He reaches out suddenly, one great hand closing over the distributor cap. He yanks, ripping the feed wires out of their sockets.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Still gripping the wires, he walks off. Doc simmers down. He turns to face Macreedy, who hasn't moved. Now Macreedy slowly lowers the hood of the car.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He walks off. Doc looks after him grimly.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (quietly) It can be fixed.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Easy. Unless, of course, this here wire... (reaching inside the hood, pointing) ...got broke or something.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (suddenly, heatedly, turning on Hector) Do the nice little things, like keep your big fat nose out of my business.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (triumphantly, holding up the wires) Yep. It's the wirin'.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (softly, after a beat) I'm sorry, son. You got to admit, I tried.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (as if to himself) Maybe...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Maybe what?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If I can't get out of town, maybe I can get the state cops in.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (irritably) You tried the phone, didn't you? You know what happened, don't you?
dialogue.name: dialogue
