dialogue.raw_text: There's another way. I'll be seeing you, Doc.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (calling) I hope you'll be seeing me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Macreedy stands at the high counter, writing on a Postal Telegraph blank. Behind the counter, watching him nervously, is Hastings. At the agent's elbow is a big pitcher with dew on the glass. It holds a pale liquid and a chunk of ice. His eyes on Macreedy, Hastings refills a glass tumbler. He takes a gulp as Macreedy puts down the pencil and pushes the message toward him. Now Hastings puts down his glass, picks up the form and scans it hurriedly. He looks at Macreedy, eyes glazed with anxiety...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hastings again refills his glass, slopping the liquid over on the counter. He picks up the glass, hesitates, offers it awkwardly to Macreedy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Macreedy shakes his head. No.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He drinks, puts down the glass. Macreedy pushes the bill across the counter toward him. Hastings picks it up gingerly then pauses...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Macreedy turns and walks out. Hastings stands sweating, staring hard at the message in his hand as...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You notifyin' the state po-lice?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (putting a bill on the counter) That's what it says.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (plaintively) Lemonade?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (mopping his forehead) It's hot as Billy-be-durned.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't you like lemonade?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I never thought much about it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It don't have the muzzle velocity of some other drinks drunk around here, but it's good for what ails you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (after a beat) What ails you, Mr. Hastings?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why are you so upset about... (points) ...this wire?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Are you afraid, Mr. Hastings?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Me...? (a beat, then softly) I guess I am. (awkwardly he puts Macreedy's bill back on the counter) But what's the use talkin'...? (with grudging respect) You don't know what it's like, being scared.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (not unsympathetically) You want me to describe the symptoms? Right this minute I'm scared half to death.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (simply) You should be.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah. But not of the state police.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (stonily) Neither am I.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then what are you afraid of? The grave at Adobe Flat? A grave nobody marked, nobody knows anything about.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That ain't it, either.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Is it Smith? (no answer) Is it?!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (squirming) Look, Mr. Macreedy. I'm just a good neighbor...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: To Smith you are. How about to Komako?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (meeting Macreedy's eyes) I never seen Komako in my life. Honest.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (again pushes the bill toward Hastings) Then send that wire, and bring me the answer. You'll do that, won't you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (pauses, then worriedly picking up the bill) Yes, sir.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Sequence omitted from original script.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: FRANKLIN KROOL, WALT MURTRY, RON BENTHAM

direction.raw_text: & GRILL A few loafers are at the bar, draped bonelessly on high stools. There is the usual array of bottles and glasses aligned before a cracked, discolored mirror. In the corner is a jukebox. Along the opposite wall is a line of low stools facing a counter covered with oil-cloth thumb-tacked in place. Behind it is a greasy hot plate and a couple of soiled displays -- breakfast food, soft drinks, etc. At the grill counter is Sam, cleaning his finger-nails with a toothpick. At the bar, engaged in a worrisome conversation, are four loafers, FRANKLIN KROOL, WALT MURTRY, RON BENTHAM and STERLING LENARD.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He looks up, and something makes him hesitate...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I tell you, I won't have anything to do with it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (nodding emphatically) Live and let live, that's what I say.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (frowning) I don't know. I just don't know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Bentham) You gonna brood about it? Or you want another beer?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A beer, I guess. Only...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: -- EXT. BAR & GRILL - MACREEDY stopping in front of the restaurant. On the window large, rough capital letters in water paint proclaim:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: & GRILL Macreedy pauses, shrugs and then enters.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: & GRILL Sam is still working on his finger nails. He evidences little interest in the stranger, but at the bar in b.g. the loafers stiffen. Macreedy takes a stool in front of Sam.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Macreedy winces.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The door of the Bar & Grill opens. Smith and Coley enter. They walk to Macreedy, stopping just a few feet behind him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He turns again as Sam plops an unseasonable mess of chili in front of him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Macreedy smiles tiredly. He half turns toward Coley.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He gets up, with his chili, and sits down three stools away. Coley straddles the stool Macreedy has vacated. He squirms on it, his movements exaggerated. Now he spins to face Smith.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Coley opens his mouth but, realizing he has been outmaneuvered, closes it again. The loafers in b.g. are silent, watching. Sam, seemingly oblivious to Coley's pressure on Macreedy, places a bottle of ketchup in front of the stranger. Coley gets up slowly and walks stiff-legged to Macreedy. He takes the bottle of ketchup and, without removing the cap, upends it over Macreedy's plate. The cap is drowned in a deluge of ketchup which overflows the plate and runs onto the counter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Macreedy rises to go out. As he passes Coley, Coley takes his limp left arm and spins him slowly but firmly around. The two men face each other.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Macreedy shakes free of Coley's grasp. Coley lunges. His big right fist streaks toward Macreedy's face. Macreedy ducks, weaving with the punch. He grabs Coley's belt, twisting Coley's body. The momentum of the swing throws Coley off balance. As he goes past Macreedy, the stranger tugs at his belt, twisting him to one side. He plants his left foot firmly on the toes of Coley's left boot, for a split second anchoring Coley in place. He chops the under side of his open hand in a short, vicious arc that lands solidly under Coley's ear. With the same motion, he brings the heel of his hand hard against and slightly under the tip of Coley's nose. The cartilage shatters. Blood spills down his face. Following through, Macreedy's elbow smashes beneath Coley's cheekbone. Macreedy's arm goes past the astonished, wind-burned face, finding Coley's right wrist. He jerks the wrist out and backward. It snaps. Coley whimpers, his face twisted in pain and perplexity. His body lolls forward. Macreedy steps back. He raises his right shoulder a few inches. His bent right arm drives up like a piston attached to the shoulder's lift. Fist and arm seem all one rigid piece with only the limber shoulder giving them motion. The fist strikes Coley's face, covering for a moment one side of his chin and a corner of his mouth between cheekbone and jawbone. Coley shuts his eyes and falls unconscious. Smith, a puzzled expression on his face, watches Coley fall. He takes half a step toward him. Macreedy looks at Smith. Smith stops. Macreedy's face is wooden, with a trace of sullenness around the hard lines of his mouth. Working methodically, Macreedy frisks Coley. He takes from a pocket a long, ugly knife. He snaps the spring and the four-inch blade leaps into place. He looks at the knife in his hand and then at Smith. He smiles gently, even dreamily.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Macreedy walks slowly toward him, holding the knife. The are only three feet apart. Smith's hand goes to a pocket, closes inside over the outline of a pistol. Sam glances from Macreedy to Smith to the unconscious Coley. He sidles toward the door and runs out fast. (NOTE: From this point to end of scene INTERCUT from Macreedy and Smith to exploit the reactions of the loafers at the bar.)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: With a quick motion, he tosses the knife to Smith. Smith catches it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He walks past Smith and goes out the door. Self-consciously holding the knife, Smith turns to face the loafers at the bar. They say nothing; they stare at him, through him, like a panel of ghouls. The door opens, admitting Sam and Doc, who carries his little black medical bag. Doc looks at Coley.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He goes to Coley, bending down over him. Smith has remained motionless as a monument. Now he doubles shut the knife in his hand. He pockets it, and without even glancing at Coley, turns quickly and goes out.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What'll you have?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What have you got?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Chili wit' beans.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Anything else?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Chili wit'out beans.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You don't like the taste, that's what they make ketchup for.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: In that case, I'll have it. And a cup of coffee.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Macreedy, with menacing friendliness) You still around? I thought you didn't like this place.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (pleasantly) Going to, or coming from?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Staying put.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No comment.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Smith, gesturing a thumb toward Macreedy) No comment, he says. No comment, and all the time he's got my chair.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I always seem to be taking somebody's place around here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This seat ain't comfortable.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I was afraid of that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I think I'd like the seat you're on.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Macreedy, mildly) He's as changeable as a prairie fire.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Coley) Suppose you tell me where to sit.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Macreedy) I hope that ain't too much.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Smith, gesturing toward Coley) Your friend's a very [...] fellow.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (nodding) Sort of unpredictable, too. Got a temper like a rattlesnake.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's me all over. I'm half hoss, half alligator. Mess with me, I'll kick a lung outta you. What do you think of that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No comment.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Talking to you is like pulling teeth. You wear me out. (loudly, after a beat) You're a yellow-bellied Jap lover. Am I right or wrong?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're not only wrong -- you're wrong at the top of your voice.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You don't like my voice?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (again turning to Smith) I think your friend's trying to start something.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Now why-ever would he want to do that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know. Maybe he figures, needle me enough and I'll crack. Maybe I'll even fight back. Then he or Hector -- your other ape -- would beat me to death and cop a plea of self-defense.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't think that'll be necessary. You're so scared now you'll probably drown in your own sweat.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Before that happens, couldn't I pick a fight with you if I tied one hand behind me...?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If I tied both hands...?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Smith) Wouldn't it be easier if you just waited till I turned my back? (looking toward the loafers at the bar, then back at Smith) Or are there too many witnesses present?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (with effortless ferocity) You're still in trouble.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So are you. (Smith snorts) Whatever happens -- you're lost.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You got things a bit twisted...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You killed Komako. Sooner or later you'll go up for it. Not because you killed him -- in this town you probably could have gotten away with it -- but because you didn't even have the guts to do it alone. You put your trust in guys like him... (gesturing toward the unconscious Coley) ...and Hector -- they're not the most dependable of God's creatures. Sooner or later they'll get the idea you're playing them for saps. What'll you do then -- peel them off, one by one? And in the meantime if any one of them breaks, you'll go down hard. Because they got something on you. Something to use when things get tough.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And they're getting tougher every minute.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (softly, full of awe) Man... man-oh-man.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Doc sits deep in the battered upholstery of one of the chairs. He stares fiercely across the room at Smith who is on the couch, reading a neatly folded newspaper. Behind him at the clerk's desk, Pete is fitfully involved in a game of solitaire. At the foot of the stairs Hector is pouring change into a slot machine. It whines, grinds, and clicks with rhythmic monotony, but it never seems to pay off. In the chair nearest Doc is Tim, with one of his boots off. He works hard and with some concentration, removing the other. Then he places them neatly at the foot of his chair. He wiggles his toes -- watching them with some interest. The wheeze and whir of the slot machine stops. The sudden silence turns the eyes of the men toward Hector and the one- arm bandit. They follow his gaze up the steps.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - MACREEDY walks down, carrying his suitcase. He goes to Pete at the clerk's desk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As Macreedy turns from the desk, Doc joins him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Smith coolly continues to read his paper. It is Hector who turns toward Doc...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Macreedy ignores the exchange of words. He walks across the frayed carpet to the nearest chair and drops into it. Doc, who has followed him, stands looking down at Macreedy for a long moment. Then...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Doc follows his gaze as Hastings enters the lobby and looks around. He sees Macreedy coming toward him. He walks rigidly in an arc past Macreedy to Smith. He holds out a Postal Telegraph form. Smith puts down his paper and takes it. Macreedy, followed by Doc, goes over to Smith. Tim in his stockinged feet joins them. Smith scans the message. He looks up to meet Macreedy's gaze. Smith rises. Hector swaggers over from the slot machine. Hastings slips around the back of the couch, protected by the barricade of Hector's great body.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hastings is silent. A brittle expression of bemusement crosses Smith's features.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Macreedy's mouth compresses in a harsh grin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Macreedy takes a step toward Hastings. The telegraph agent bounces away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tim hesitates, blinking his eyes worriedly, shifting from one stockinged foot to the other. Smith watches him insolently as he takes the message from Macreedy and gestures with it vaguely...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He reaches out, clawing the badge from Tim's chest. He jabs it on Hector's vest.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hector moves his elephantine bulk within inches of Macreedy...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Macreedy doesn't answer. Hector takes the message from Tim's limp hand and tears it into little pieces.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Macreedy doesn't answer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He walks out, the new Sheriff strutting beside him, with Hastings in their wake. For a moment Macreedy, Doc and Tim stand in the center of the lobby. Pete eyes them non- committally and goes back to his solitaire. He glances up now and then, moving the cards with a purposeful sort of slowness, as of a more natural swiftness restrained by his preoccupation with the three men in the lobby. Macreedy is deep in thought. Abstractedly he tugs at his collar and then repeats the ritual of lighting a cigarette. Tim's shoulders are slumped. Humiliation has corroded him, flesh and soul. Even Doc is momentarily subdued; he too, feels degraded, unclean. Macreedy looks from one to the other of the good, ineffectual companions that circumstance has so haphazardly tossed his way. He takes a few steps to his suitcase, Doc and Tim trailing him; Doc, for want of something better to do; Tim, out of his deep, inexpressible need for support. Macreedy takes an untapped bottle of whiskey from his bag. He thumbs the cork loose and holds the bottle out to Tim. Tim takes a drink. The light on the clerk's desk goes on, and we are aware that day has gone and that night is falling. The pressing, fierce light has drained from the lobby, leaving a shadowy, silvery dreariness. The shadows have lengthened and the silver has tarnished with the darkness.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pete comes out from behind the desk, walking from one lamp in the lobby to another, turning them on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He hands Doc the whiskey bottle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He downs a snort, then looks at Pete, who approaches them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As Pete turns on the lamp behind Doc, he reacts ever so slightly to Doc's words. His almost imperceptible grimace is not lost on Macreedy. Macreedy watches the young man as he continues to light the lamps...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Doc slams the whiskey bottle down on a nearby table.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Self-consciously Pete has backed off until now he leans against the outside of the clerk's desk. But he still can't shut his ears to what Doc is saying...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tim sighs, running a thick hand over his forehead...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There is a moment of crashing silence. Then...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Slowly he lumbers out of the lobby. Doc watches him go. Again the benumbing silence, cut finally, unexpectedly by...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: His right hand closes over the neck of the whiskey bottle on the end table. Abstractedly fingering it, he walks with tense, deliberate steps toward Pete at the desk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He continues to advance inexorably toward Pete.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He is now within a couple of yards of Pete.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: For a moment Pete stares at Macreedy, terribly disturbed by the incisiveness of Macreedy's analysis. Then...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In sudden frustration, Pete grabs the deck of cards on the clerk's desk and slams them down hard. They scatter. He turns, stares blankly [...] between Doc and Macreedy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pete doesn't answer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pete nods helplessly, bowing his head. Macreedy sighs, looks down at the bottle in his hand, slowly puts it on the table...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Silence. Doc, realizing the enormity of Macreedy's admission, frowns, rubs a hand across his tired eyes. Pete looks at Macreedy for a long, shocked moment. He shivers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He takes the bottle from the table and shakily pours a shot glass of liquor. As he raises it to his mouth...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pete is motionless, holding the glass inches from his lips, hypnotized by Macreedy's voice, as hard and as cold as his eyes...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Macreedy's hand shoots out, in a short, inexorable arc, smashing his palm across the shot glass. The whiskey bursts in a spray, the glass flies halfway across the room, shattering as it lands against something solid. Pete is stunned, Doc perplexed, at Macreedy's violence. They stare at him... Macreedy's eyes are murky. The creases between the brows over his nose are deep. His nostrils move in and out with his breathing. Pete and Doc regard him with growing uneasiness. Rage comes into Macreedy's face, turning it a painful red.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pete squirms under Macreedy's relentless attack.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Macreedy grabs the bottle, shoving it across the table toward Pete.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pete pushes the bottle aside, too ravaged by Macreedy's words and his own thoughts to drink. He shakes his head grimly and then, with sudden decision, goes to the switchboard and plugs in a line.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Anything for me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nothing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Any message -- a telegram?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (returning to his cards) Nothing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Macreedy, shrilly, gruffly) In case you're interested, Coley'll live. (glaring at Smith and Hector) I'm truly sorry to say.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Doc, jerking a fat hand toward Macreedy) Your friend's pretty tough.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah. He's wicked. He defends himself when he's attacked.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (with some irritation) Well...? You going to just sit here and let time run out?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm waiting for a wire. From the state cops.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You sent it through Hastings? (an audible sigh) Just don't expect an answer, if that's the way you sent it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (looking toward the door) No? (he rises)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (evenly, to Smith) I think that's for me. (he takes the message from Smith's hand and quickly glances at it. Looking up at Hastings) Where's the answer?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You expect an answer -- to a wire that's never sent?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's so funny?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nothing. Just a thought -- (his eyes turn to Hastings. Hastings wilts)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: a thought dazzling in its purity...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (slowly) You're in a jam, Hastings. You gave my telegram to Smith.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (excitedly) You warty wretch! That's a federal offense!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Smith) You're in deep, too. (grins hard) Like I said, it's getting tougher and tougher. (to Tim) Sheriff, you'd better do something about this.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Smith) I reckon that's right, Mr. Smith...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't be a jerk, Tim.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Smith, seriously) Divulging information -- there's a law...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Tim, you're pathetic.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (doggedly) Could be. But I'm still Sheriff.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's the point. You're not Sheriff any more. You just lost a job, you're so pathetic.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Hector) All right, Sheriff. Take over.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You can't do that!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Can't I? I put him in office. Now I take him out.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Now. You want to register a complaint?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: To register a complaint, boy, you've got to have evidence. You got evidence?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You got a big mouth, boy, makin' accusations, disturbin' the peace. There's laws in this county protectin' innocent folks from big mouths. Why, I'd just hate to...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (interrupting) Hector... (wearily) Come on, Hector.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (hopefully) It's all right, Tim. We're not licked yet.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (numbly) Ain't we? I am.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There comes a time, Tim, when a man's just got to do something.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not me. I'm useless, and I know it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (imploring) No man is useless, if he's got a friend...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm your friend, Tim.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then let me alone.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (jabbing at Macreedy with a thumb) He's going to need you before the night is over.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (contemptuously) And all the useful men are on the other side.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (angrily) Lemme alone, I tell ya!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I can't let you alone! I can't let myself alone! Don't you understand that? (he turns from Tim to Pete, who is unable to shake his gaze. Then, sadly, fiercely) Four years ago something terrible happened here. We did nothing about it. Nothing. The whole town fell into a sort of settled melancholy, and the people in it closed their eyes and held their tongues and failed the test with a whimper.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Now something terrible is going to happen again, and in a way we're lucky because we've been given a second chance. And this time I won't close my eyes, I won't hold my tongue, and if I'm needed I won't fail. (almost harshly, again facing Tim) And neither will you!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I got such a headache, I'm bewildered. I hurt all over.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know -- (unconsciously his right arm strays to massage the paralyzed left)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: pain is bewildering. I came here bewildered, full of self-pity, afraid to fight back. (gesturing with his hand to Pete) And then your friend Smith tried to kill me. (the muscles around Pete's mouth tighten) Funny, how a man clings to the earth when he feels there's a chance he may never see it again.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There's a difference between clinging to the earth... (eyeing Tim almost contemptuously) ...and crawling on it. You going to stand by and watch forever?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (flatly) I ain't gonna watch, and I ain't gonna get into it, either.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm gettin' out. I'm sorry, Mr. Macreedy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Doc) You'd be smart to get out, too.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (angrily turning to Pete) There's too many smart guys around here. I'm glad I'm a dummy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're a troublesome dummy. You're liable to end up on your own slab...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (heatedly) I expect to be in a lot more trouble before I die...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Go home, Doc. (he jerks his head toward Macreedy, and with mock bravado...) He's all washed up.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (grinning harshly at him) You think so?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I was washed up when I got off that train...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (flatly) You shouldn' of got off.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Had to. I had one last duty to perform before I resigned from the human race.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (quizzically) I thought you were going to Los Angeles, that hot-bed of pomp and vanity. Is that resigning from the human race?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (shrugging) L.A.'s a good jumping off place -- for the Islands, for Mexico, Central America.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (again shrugs) I don't know. I was looking for a place to get lost, I guess.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (slapping his paralyzed arm with the whisky bottle) Because of this. I thought I'd never be able to function again. (turning to Pete) Thanks to your friend Smith, I found I was wrong.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (drily) Sure. You're a man of action.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (slowly) I know your problem. (with mounting vigor) You'd like me to die quickly, without wasting too much of your time... (Pete opens his mouth to say something, but Macreedy presses on) ...or silently, without making you feel too uncomfortable... or thankfully, without making your memories of the occasion too unpleasant.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (bitterly) My memories are so pleasant as it is...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (quietly pressing his advantage) What happened, Pete?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Are you going to tell him -- or you want me to? (beat) Smith owns Adobe Flat. He leased it to Komako -- thought he had cheated him, thought Komako could never even run stock without water. There was never any water on Adobe Flat. Komako dug a well, by hand. He must have went down one hundred and fifty feet.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He got water, plenty. Smith was pretty sore. He didn't like Japs anyway.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's an understatement.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The day after Pearl Harbor, Smith went to Sand City.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (interrupting) I know. To enlist. He was turned down.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He was sore when he got back. About ten o'clock he started drinking.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ten o'clock in the morning.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah. Hector joined him, and Coley. Then Sam, and about nine p.m. -- me. We were all drunk -- patriotic drunk. We went out to Komako's for a little fun, I guess -- scare him a little.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Did you know him?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We'd seen him around some, but none of us knew him. When he heard us coming, he locked the door. Smith started a fire. The Jap came running out. His clothes were burning. Smith shot him. I didn't even know Smith had a gun.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then you all got scared, buried him, kept quiet.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (softly) Did Komako have any family besides his son Joe?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (puzzled) His son...? Nobody around here knew he had a son.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He had one. But he's dead, too. He's buried in Italy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What are you doing here, Mr. Macreedy?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Joe Komako died in Italy, saving my life. They gave him a medal. I came here to give it to his father.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (awfully) God forgive me...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Pete, harshly guttural) It'll take a lot of whiskey to wash out your guts...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...And it will never help -- not even a barrel full washes away murder!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But maybe I'm wrong. Go on -- drink. (scornfully) What else is left for you?! (mounting anger) You're as dead as Komako, only you don't know it! (roaring) You also don't know that it's not enough to feel guilty. It's not enough to confess. It's not enough to say, "Forgive me, I've done wrong."
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Take it easy, Macreedy. Sit down.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (turning on him) Sit down?! Or would you rather have me kneel, to beg his pardon for raising a touchy subject?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (shaking his head) You don't have to remind me. I've never forgotten...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, that's mighty noble of you. You feel ashamed -- that's noble, too. (in mounting crescendo) And four years from now you'll probably be sitting here telling somebody else you haven't forgotten me. That's progress -- you'll still be ashamed but I'll be dead.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Go on, have your drink. (with exorbitant scorn) You need it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (leaning over counter, staring at him) What are you doing?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (into phone, ignoring Doc) Hello, Liz. Now listen... I... 'm getting Macreedy out of town...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: as they exchange a glance. Doc takes a long, deep breath of relief. Macreedy frowns thoughtfully. He strains to listen to Liz, but all he (and we) can hear is the staccato jumble of her words over the wire.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: R ANGLE - FAVORING PETE he cuts Liz short...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Again Liz's voice incoherent over the phone, and again...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Slowly he replaces the phone on the switch-board. He comes around from behind the desk, joining Macreedy and Doc.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (into phone) I don't care about Smith! Let him try to kill me -- I might as well be dead as...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (into phone, interrupting) Liz, Liz... There's not much of me left any more, but however little it is I won't waste it! (again Liz's voice briefly; then...) I'm telling you because we need your help. (again Liz's voice) ...No matter about the past -- you've got to do this! You'd be saving two lives, Liz. Macreedy's, and mine. (again Liz answers and...) All right. Yeah... I've told him everything.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (flatly) She'll be here in five minutes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thanks, Pete. Thanks very much.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Pete and Doc are nervously alert, drained of energy, waiting. Hector is downright bored. He toys with his pistol, squinting at it, twirling the barrel. Finding neither interest nor pleasure in the piece, he jams it back in his holster and strolls with exaggerated surety out on the porch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The congregation of loafers look up as Hector emerges. Imbued with his own bullying importance, he draws the pistol, maneuvers an extravagant pinwheel and a few other gaudy tricks. Then he sighs as boredom again takes over. He walks down the steps to catch a bit of air.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The disappearance of Hector (o.s.) down the street galvanizes them into action. They hurry out of the lobby toward the back of the hotel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Vague in the pallid light escaping through a few back windows. The hotel's rear door is tightly shut. Around the far corner of the street (extreme b.g.) comes the gangling body of Hector David. He walks toward CAMERA. Perhaps twenty-five yards away he stops to rest against a fence like a leaning tower.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: His hand goes to a pocket and comes out with a crumpled half pack of cigarettes. Suddenly the movement is arrested; something at the other end of the street captures his bleak attention.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A jeep, headlights off, slowly turns the corner, pulls up to the curb and parks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - HECTOR pockets his cigarettes and starts slowly for the jeep, a quizzical frown on his horsy face. He approaches the back door of the hotel, oblivious to it as he continues toward the jeep.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: At the far end b.g., toward the lobby, a single unshaded light bulb burns dully. A slight figure stands in f.g. To one side is a narrow U-shaped alcove blanketed in heavy shadows. The features of the man in the hall and the slim lines of his body blend vaguely in the darkness. With enormous care, he turns a knob and opens the door leading to the alley behind the hotel. Light thrown by the back windows reveals that the figure is Pete. The same pallid light from the alley, glancing across the alcove, momentarily illuminates it. Glued as close to the recessed wall as is humanly possible is Doc. He is partially shielded by one of those hotel hose wheels around which an old fire hose is wound. The heavy brass nozzle of the hose hangs from the end. Doc grips a twelve-inch length of lead pipe. Pete swallows nervously and peers outside, first to the right, then to the left. His eyes glaze with fear, and his jaw tightens with tension.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: as he stares at Hector walking toward the jeep.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hector stops, turns to face Pete. He hesitates, then...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then, with a final glance at the jeep, Hector lumbers to Pete, who disappears inside the hallway.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (controlling his jangled nerves) Hector!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hmmmm?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: as Hector enters and stops. Pete quickly closes the door behind him and walks toward the lobby, attempting to draw Hector toward the black alcove center screen b.g. But Hector is not to be sucked in. He glares at Pete, waiting. (NOTE: The following dialogue is delivered sotto voce.)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He jams a cigarette in his mouth. Pete watches him frantically as he searches his pockets for a match. He can't find one.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He starts to turn. Hector's pig eyes are slits of suspicion. Before Pete can move, Hector reaches out, hooking two heavy fingers inside a pocket of Pete's shirt. Slowly Hector's expression changes to one of insidious cunning. His fingers come out of Pete's pocket, and between them is a paper book of matches.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pete is unable to answer. He is scared to death.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What you want?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's still in his room. Macreedy, I mean.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So...? You want me to tuck him in?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I thought maybe you wanted to tell Smith.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (explaining something he feels Pete already knows) Smith said he'd be here at midnight. He don't want to be disturbed.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You got a match?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Come on. I got some in the lobby.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I thought you didn't have a match.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: sweating with frustration. Hector is six feet away, and armed -- too far away for Doc to risk an attack with his lead pipe. Doc looks around vaguely, wildly, for another weapon. A fraction of an inch from his nose is the hose wheel. For a split second he hesitates. Then slowly, with infinite care, he tightens the heavy brass nozzle and begins to unwind the hose.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now Hector is alert. He studies Pete's twitching face. Elaborately he tears a match from the pack and scratches it. It takes fire, cupped in the rampart of his big hands. It lights up the hall, and as Hector looks around he sees something through a mirror -- over his shoulder and six feet away Doc materializes out of the shadows of the alcove. As Hector whirls, going for his gun, Doc swings the hose with sudden deadly aim. It uncoils like a snake, and the brass nozzle crashes with a mighty thud across Hector's skull. Hector groans. He sinks unconscious to the floor. Doc stands there, paralyzed by his action. Pete tears toward the lobby.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: as Pete rushes in. He moves directly to the desk, leans over and presses the buzzer behind the desk three times. He turns and runs back toward the rear of the building.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: as Macreedy barrels down. He pauses briefly in the hall as he sees Doc still standing with the hose and the nozzle dangling like a pendulum from his hand. Their eyes lock briefly in understanding...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He heads toward the alley.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (with a half smile) I'll never forgive you, Doc... (he gestures toward Hector, out cold) ...for depriving me of that pleasure.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: as Macreedy rushes out. He pauses, looking quickly right, then left. He sees a jeep parked at the curb far down the street. He runs toward it. The jeep, its headlights off, starts for him. He swings onto the moving vehicle, falling heavily into the seat beside Liz Brooks. He slumps there, breathing heavily as the jeep, with a grinding of gears, cuts through the night, picking up speed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: as Pete joins Doc. Silently, motionlessly, the two men stare for a long moment at Hector -- particularly at the pistol lying beside him. Then they look at each other, and the same thought seems to flash in their minds...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: as they speed down the long empty ribbon of road. Liz drives hard. Macreedy turns in the bucket seat, looking back toward Black Rock.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Macreedy does not answer.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Sorry I can't get more out of this heap.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (with a burst of irritation) We could make better time with a dog team.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (calmly) You're doing the best you can. (a beat) Aren't you, Liz?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't expect too much from me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (dryly) Don't worry, I won't.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (quickly) I mean, people have always expected things from me. You know why? Because I'm pretty. Well, that's not enough.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: with Liz and Macreedy as she cuts sharply into a crossroad. She drives skillfully over the knotty road which is little more than a trail. Her lovely features are distorted with her discontent and the ache for attention. After a moment she gives voice to her fantasy...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He does not catch the glance she darts him; his extreme awareness is anchored not to the girl at his side but to the terrain ahead.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: His eyes strain to sweep the country -- each boulder, each outcropping, each stunted tree. But substance and shadow are blurred and fuzzy in the dark night, black on black.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (softly) Maybe I could have been something -- a model, or something. (glancing at him) You don't believe that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes I do.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, I don't, really. I'm a dime a dozen.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That I don't believe.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm too little and too late.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's never too late.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I lack the muscle.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (frowning) Why is muscle so important?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (cynically) Oh, you're the brainy type. (harshly) Did it take brains to rough up Coley? Whatever you did to Hector, you didn't do it with brains. How'd you get Pete to change his mind?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not with muscle.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And not with brains, either. He's a pushover for a muscle man.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm beginning' to think it runs in the family. (looking at her hard) You think strength is in the width of a man's shoulders.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'd sure have liked to see you tangle with Reno Smith.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He wasn't around when I left... Maybe I will yet.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Sequence omitted from original script.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: with Macreedy and Liz as it winds to the far end of the boulders on a trail that drops off into a flat basin. Solid forms loom up in the darkness; they are unrecognizable, yet Macreedy senses some tense familiarity with the terrain... He frowns. Suddenly Liz brakes the jeep -- so sharply Macreedy lurches forward in the seat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She moves away from Macreedy to get out of the jeep. He reaches across quickly, gripping her arm. She turns to face him, disturbed by his hardness of jaw and eye...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Suddenly they are hit by a blinding pair of headlights like [...] The beams cut jaggedly through the night, throwing into sharp immediate relief the lava rocks, the broken windmill, the gutted house, the litter-strewn, unmarked grave at Adobe Flat. Liz throws away the ignition key. Macreedy bails out of the jeep, still holding the girl.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (alert, expectant) What's this?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (vamping nervously) We need water... (she turns off engine, pulling ignition key from its lock) ...radiator's overheating.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Leggo! Leggo of me!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: TWO SHOT - LIZ AND MACREEDY as they fall to the earth. Macreedy pins her down. Then in quick succession, four emphatically loud SHOTS from a rifle squirt into the shale around them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He looks up blindly into the headlights glaring from the granitic high ground some 60 yards away. His grip on the girl's shoulder is like a steel trap. He pushes her down beside Komako's grave, hugging the side of the jeep as a SHOT rips the gravel at their feet. Pulling the girl with him, he takes cover in the slight concavity of the grave. The jeep is between them and the headlights -- between them and the source of the gunfire. Liz struggles to break away. Suddenly bullets kick up a storm around him. A bullet smashes into the flowers, exploding tiny cruel fragments of dirt into Macreedy's face. He gasps in pain, releasing Liz. He rubs his eyes as if to convince himself that he is not blind. Liz breaks from the grave. Now, five yards from Macreedy... LIZ (calling toward the headlights) Smitty! Smitty!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Liz half turns, facing Macreedy with a vicious smile...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She starts toward the headlights.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (harshly, through his teeth) You're stupid, Liz. You're a fool. If he finishes me, he's got to finish you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (o.s.) I'm here, honey. Just head for the car.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (an almost bantering voice) So long, Macreedy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: She reaches the foot of the rocky ridge, with the two enormous eyes on top. She begins to climb, up... up...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She is almost at the top; a vertically sheer rock about five feet high separates her from it. She looks up at Smith, towering over her at the edge of the precipice. He holds his rifle almost languorously.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The girl is frightened by the menace in Smith's voice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He brings the rifle down, aiming almost casually at Liz. Her eyes go wide. She steps back, spins around, running crazily down the steep incline.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (o.s.) Just a few more steps, honey.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (breathlessly) Get him! Get him now!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (easily) First things first, honey.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (unsure, reaching out her hand) Help me up, Smitty.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You were going to help me, Liz. (she looks at him quizzically) I still need your help.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (confused) I did what you said...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You two started out in a car. That's the way you'll end up. Over a cliff, burning. (she tries to interrupt him, but he goes on...) You can blame that on Macreedy, too. He said I had too many witnesses.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (dry whisper) But why me? Why start with me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I got to start with somebody.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (yelling wildly) Macreedy! Macreedy!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: rings out. She falls forward, rolling slowly down the embankment. She lies there. Blood trickles from the corner of her pretty mouth. A rattling noise rises from deep in her throat, and then subsides. In the silence the outline of Reno Smith emerges. Holding his rifle at the ready, his silhouette illuminated sharply in the twin beams of light, he climbs down the side of the cliff. He looks toward the jeep and Macreedy, not once at the girl at his feet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Smith pays no attention to her. He advances inexorably with rifle held at his hip. He fires at Macreedy.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (sadly, almost reproachfully) You shouldn't have done that...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Macreedy wipes the last of the fragments from his eyes. His face is still streaked with dirt and shale. He turns, searching for something, anything, to fight back with. Then he remembers... Stiffening, his body set, his eyes narrow, he moves purposefully toward the front of the jeep and crawls under it. Again Smith opens up on him. Bullet after bullet pours into the confined space, nicking the wall, ricocheting off the jeep with a frightening, fluttery, wheezing sound. The firing stops again and in the silence we HEAR a familiar TRICKLE, as in running water...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: re-loads his rifle. Stiffly, he starts slowly down over the rocks toward his unarmed victim...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He has unscrewed the nut and unconnected the gas line with the carburator. A spurt of gasoline is running out. With a quick motion he picks up an empty whisky bottle from the litter-strewn earth. He fills it with gasoline, quickly screws the nut back on. Now he sweeps his necktie free of his collar. Holding it with his teeth, he tears the felt lining free from its silk face. He twists half the lining inside the bottle, knotting the other end securely around the bottle's neck, leaving a long strand dangling.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: moving rigidly toward the hole. He stops, levels his rifle, fires.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: pinned down in the direct line of fire. The burst of the rifle stops.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: not more than twenty-five yards away, advancing carefully, rifle at the ready.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: lights a match, placing the flame to the dangling end of the tie. It catches. He flings himself to his feet and with the same motion whips the fiery bottle like a football, hard and straight toward Smith. Smith fires once, fast and wild. The bottle crashes against the rocks at his feet and bursts with a shattering explosion. Smith screams as the razor-sharp slivers rip his flesh. In a puff of flame, his clothes ignite. He drops the rifle and goes down, squirming frantically on the black ashy ground.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: favoring Macreedy as he tears out of the hole. He hurls himself at Smith. Wooden-faced, almost dreamy-eyed, he shovels the ashy dirt over Smith's prone chest, putting out the fire. Smith struggles halfway to his feet. Macreedy grabs his shoulder, helping him up. Smith looks at Macreedy through eyes bleary with fear and pain and shock.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He drives his right fist against Smith's chin. Smith's head snaps back as far as it can go and then wobbles to rest on his chest. He collapses. Macreedy blows out his breath hard. He staggers to Liz. As he bends over her...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (through his teeth) Go ahead -- kill me. Now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'd like to kill you now, but you caused too much pain to die quickly. (a beat) You'll be tried in a court of law. You'll be convicted by a jury. Then you'll die.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Liz's jeep, driven by Macreedy, rolls slowly down the empty main street of the sleeping town. Behind him, under a tarp, the body of the girl lies lifeless across the seat. On the seat beside him is Smith's rifle, the balance a few inches from Macreedy's elbow. On the right front fender of the jeep Smith sits precariously, his shirt scorched and ragged. He wears a sullen expression of pained indifference. In b.g., as the jeep passes, isolated lights go on, first in Doc's house, then in two or three others. Macreedy is oblivious to them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: almost completely hidden, looks out grimly from a corner of the jail window. Protruding through the bars, swiveling to follow the progress of the jeep down the street, is the long, ugly muzzle of a rifle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: as Macreedy pulls up to the curb in front of the jail and cuts the ignition. He grabs the rifle, and steps around to Smith.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Smith complies.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (tonelessly, prodding Smith off the fender with his rifle) Hands behind your head.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: as Macreedy marches Smith up the steps. The jail door opens. A man emerges, wearing a Mackinaw over his vest and carrying a rifle. It is Tim. For a moment Macreedy eyes him in silence. His gun finger tightens on the rifle in his hand. Tim's rifle, too, is at the ready...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The SOUND of running feet padding along the dirt road increases on SOUND TRACK. Macreedy turns slightly, to see Doc huffing toward him. The older man climbs the jail steps and comes to an abrupt halt, his eyes going from one to the other of the two men in the stand-off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He pulls Tim's Mackinaw to one side, revealing the silver- plated star pinned at the breast.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Macreedy swings his rifle from Tim to Smith. Tim lowers his, stepping to one side, allowing Smith, covered by Macreedy, to enter the jail. He goes in, Doc following. Pete sits silently at Tim's desk.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (after a beat) Am I going to have trouble with you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nope. But I sure thought the situation was going to be like reversed. I thought I was going to have trouble... (nodding sharply in Smith's direction) ...with him. I'll take care of him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (still hesitating) Just as you took care of his buddies?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Just as I took care of his buddies. Me, an' Doc, and Pete...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Macreedy) It's all right, Macreedy...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Old Tim here's got his badge back.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: In one of the two cells are Coley and Hector. In the other, Sam and Hastings.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tim turns his key in the cell door. Macreedy tiredly goes to Pete at the desk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pete rises. Macreedy halts him momentarily, gripping his arm...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pete walks dazedly out the door. Tim grabs Smith's shoulder and propels him roughly through the cell door. He slams it hard. As the clatter of the iron door reverberates harshly...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (looking around) Well. The gang is all here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I thought I'd take one last whack at my job. Even if Smith killed me for it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (jerking his head toward Smith) Put him in with Hastings.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Your sister's outside, Pete.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (flatly) She's dead.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The townspeople, with Doc f.g., are gathered silently in the street, staring sadly, dumbly at the hotel before them. Doc wears a dark business suit, neat and conservative. The door opens (o.s.) and the people look up, their eyes lighting with expectancy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Macreedy comes out of the door, carrying his suitcase. For a moment he pauses, looking at the uplifted faces of the people in the street. In the distance we HEAR the horn of a stream- liner. Macreedy goes down the steps, skirts the watching crowd and heads for the railroad station. Almost immediately Doc falls in step with him. The townspeople, still silent, trail after them
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: in f.g., the townspeople behind them. In b.g., as we pass, we see the main street just as we saw it when Macreedy entered town a few short hours ago.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Doc nods. He blinks and frowns...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (walking, after a beat, to Doc) Tim knows where to find me if I'm needed.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's on your mind, Doc?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nothing. Only... about that medal. Can we have it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: "We...?" Can who have it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We. (indicating the townspeople, with a vague wave of his hand) Us.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, we need it, I guess. It's something we can maybe build on. This town is wrecked, just as bad as if it was bombed out. Maybe it can come back...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Some towns come back. Some don't. It depends on the people.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: o.s. attracts Macreedy's attention. He turns, as do Doc and the townsmen.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: A PRESS CARD IN HIS HAT

direction.raw_text: In front of the jail, each of them handcuffed, are Smith, Coley, Hector, Sam and Hastings. Tim and four cops escort them to two State Police cars which are parked beside Tim's old sedan and another car (presumably belonging to a member of the press). The newspaperman (WITHOUT A PRESS CARD IN HIS HAT) stands to one side with Pete. Pete as well as Tim have changed clothes; they look clean and trim. Coley has his arm in a sling. Hector's hat hides the bandage on his head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Macreedy resumes walking toward the abandoned station, with Doc at his side and the people behind him. The train pulls in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Macreedy is silent. He walks on, to the platform. He pauses, looking at the people silently in his wake and then at Doc. He takes a black velvet-covered box from his pocket -- the box containing the medal -- looks at it, and slowly hands it to Doc.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Macreedy turns and exits from SHOT. The people look after him.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (still pressing) That medal would help.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thanks, Macreedy. Thanks for everything.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: as Macreedy boards the train.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The cars in front of the jail U-turn and start off with the prisoners. The people move silently toward the train.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Macreedy is at the passageway. Slowly the train moves out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Macreedy and a conductor stand at the doorway. The town is seen behind them and the people standing there. In the distance, Tim's car recedes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He walks into the train.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (curiously) What's the excitement? What happened?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A shooting.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I knew it was something. First time a streamliner stopped here in four years.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Second time.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: gathering speed, diminishing, far, far into the horizon.
direction.name: direction
